data.title: Stroudsburg grad takes his place among music professionals
data.meta_description: Stroudsburg native Evan Gregor, 21, performed with guitarist Pat Metheny, vibraphonist Gary Burton and drummer Jordan Perlson on Friday, April 30, in Boston, Mass.The concert was part of The Pat Meth…
data.text:
Stroudsburg native Evan Gregor, 21, performed with guitarist Pat Metheny, vibraphonist Gary Burton and drummer Jordan Perlson on Friday, April 30, in Boston, Mass.The concert was part of The Pat Metheny Group's "Nothing Conservatory About It" series at Berklee College of Music in Boston. Tickets were sold out in one day.Gregor, a 2000 graduate of Stroudsburg High School, will also represent the college at the Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C., in May as part of a quartet. He will perform in a series of jazz festivals with the Rainbow All-star Band as well as at Martha's Vineyard in a quintet with trombonist Phil Wilson and with Syncopation to open for Gary Burton and Makoto Ozone.Gregor, son of Jim and Joyce Gregor of Stroudsburg, began studying electric bass at age 13. Along with scholastic and community ensembles, he played with bands at Lehigh University under Bill Warfield, various events at Moravian College, performed and wrote music for the COTA Cats (a student ensemble founded by Phil Woods, where he has since servedas a clinician), and performed regularly in northeast Pennsylvania and New Jersey during his early teenage years.He graduated high school in three years and in 2000 received a scholarship to Berklee College of Music, where he began "doubling" on acoustic bass. He received the Outstanding Performer Award for bassists and the Charles Mingus Award for his major, Jazz Composition.He was selected to perform in concerts and clinics with visiting artists Paquito D'Rivera and Michel Camilo. Gregor was also part of student quartets led by pianist Mamiko Watanabe and Rafael Alcala that represented Berklee through a series of concerts in Japan and Washington, D.C., respectively. He performed in more than 70 student concerts at Berklee and was a member of handpicked ensembles led by Hal Crook, Joe Lovano, Dave Samuels, Herb Pomeroy and Phil Wilson's Rainbow All-star Band, and has been getting more work as a sideman in the Boston area.He spent July 2002 in Denmark doing a series of gigs and recordings, and has recorded, toured Japan, and worked as the regular bassist with vocal group Syncopation, which recently performed at the IAJE.He was the featured young artist for East Stroudsburg University's Jazz Masters Seminar in 2003 and led a group at the 2003 Delaware Water Gap Celebration of the Arts with special guest saxophonist David Liebman.

Festival for Eaton, E-burg High alumnus — — A Garden of Eaton Mini-Festival will celebrate the music of East Stroudsburg native John Eaton.At 5:30 p.m. Tuesday, May 18, a symposium, "The Acting Instrumentalist: The Pocket Operas of John Eaton" with Robert Morgan, Robert Dick, Rhoda Levine and others, will be presented at the vestibule of Theater — of Tribeca Performing Arts Center, Chambers and Washington streets, New York City. Admission is free.On Tuesday, May 18, at 8 p.m., The Pocket Opera Players will present the world premiere of "Pinocchio," a romp for instrumentalists, featuring the NY New Music Ensemble, starring Jean Kopperud as Pinocchio, conducted by James Baker and directed by Rhoda Levine, and the NY premiere of "Antigone," a Pocket Opera, starring Robert Samels, Sharon Quattrin, Marcy Richardson, Hyoun-Soo Sohn, Ulises Solano, David Eggar and Meighan Stoops, conducted by Carmen Helena Tellez and directed by Nicholas Rudall. Both works are by John Eaton. The premieres will be held in Theater — of the Tribeca Performing Arts Center. Tickets are $20, $12 for students and seniors.On Wednesday, May 19, at 2 p.m., a showing of Eaton's "Myshkin," Peabody Award-winning opera for television, and "The Lion and Androcles," an opera for children also shown on national television, is set for Theater — of the Tribeca Performing Arts Center. Admission is free.At 5:30 p.m., "The Electronic Music of John Eaton" with Marc Battier, Joel Chadabe and Robert Moog will be presented in Theater — of Tribeca Performing Arts Center. Admission is free.And at 8 p.m., The Pocket Opera Players present "Pinocchio" and "Antigone" in Theater — of the Tribeca Performing Arts Center. Tickets are $20, $12 for students and seniors.Tickets may be purchased at (212) 220-1460 or online at .Eaton, a 1955 graduate of East Stroudsburg High School, is a professor emeritus of music composition at the University of Chicago, founder of the Pocket Opera Players and composer of opera using microtonal techniques.East Stroudsburg University is home to the John Eaton Collection, which contains more than 85 scores, including 14 operas as well as orchestral, chamber and instrumental works on video, audio cassettes and CDs.
